 I hate to keep sniping at this since it seems as though you feel the same way I do about the general issue, but again I must disagree. 
 
 I agree that many do find the action of firebombing a city to be a terrible act. I will even go as far as saying that it is tragic in it's scope of destruction and loss of life. However, in regards to Dresden it is important to look at the reasons for the bombing, most importantly the consequences of not bombing the city in the first place. Dresden was not about retribution or punishment of the German people. The bombing served a strategic end designed to cripple the military capabilities of the Germans and potentiate the Russian advance on the eastern front. Looking on a grand scale, Dresden was about the salvation of millions of innocent victims. Ending the war came with the benefit of saving countless millions of lives. 
 
 Had the allies won the war and continued to firebomb German cities, I would certainly find such actions nothing more than pointless and malicious retribution. Of coarse, we stopped bombing German cities and killing German citizens when Germany surrendered. The difference is, had the Germans won the war, a mass genocide would have continued indeffinately costing countless lives in gas chambers, shooting galleries, and crematories. 
 
 I agree that war is always tragic in that innocent people die. I disagree however that "saintliness" and war are incompatible. Surely those who would have died at the hands of the Germans had the allies lost the war or turned a blind eye must find our actions saintly. Risking ones life for total strangers against a cruel and brutal enemy carries a certain nobility. It's a simple matter of perspective.
